subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] keyboard/lexical set proposal
msgSnippet: ... I think a vote may be the only way to solve the matter, but what constitutes a fair vote? We might just get 10 people voting is what I am afraid of. Also,
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> I've been tracking the proposals in a spreadsheet. I've just put a copy
> here:
>
> http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/qs_keybd_proposals.xls
> <http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/qs_keybd_proposals.xls>
>
> This is just a tab-delimited text file--it should be fine in any
> spreadsheet program or text editor. John, I've added a column for you
> with a single entry: D for #8. Paul and Peter--the columns with your
> names are from your original proposals. I haven't tried to track the
> changes you've each made. If you'd like to update the columns under
> your names, please do so. I propose a contest, to be voted on by the
> group. At this point, the floor is open for additional proposals. The
> one rule I'd like to adhere to is this: to be considered valid, an
> entry must have an assignment for all 46 letters (this includes the
> two alternates) and 3 punctuation marks. The assignments must be to
> 7-bit ASCII characters, i.e. the first 128 characters is this table:
> http://www.asciitable.com/ <http://www.asciitable.com/> (the printable
> ones, of course).
>
> Let's have a deadline for entries: Midnight (UTC), 31 December 2007.
>
> How does that sound?
>

I think a vote may be the only way to solve the matter, but what
constitutes a fair vote? We might just get 10 people voting is what I am
afraid of.

Also, I don't know if I agree that a proposal should include the two
half letters. That seems arbitrary, since there are many other half
letters as well, and we could spend months discussing how to include them.

Paul
